instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00426: What is 820-00426? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
I have this machine that had liquid damage in the area of the lcd connector and thunderbolt ports. The connector looks fine and I have ultrasonic'd the board already. The machine turns on and chimes but I get no backlight. When I shine a flashlight I can see an image on the screen. I have tried a PRAM reset but that did not work. I thought the LCD cable might have been the issue so I tried with another cable plugged in but still no backlight. 

On backlight output at the LCD connector I get 0v. On pins 3/4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> I get 12.56v and 12.44v but 0v on the output pins 1/2/5/6. <RESISTOR>R7701</RESISTOR>/2 measure proper resistance. <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.4v
I replaced <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> but that still did not solve the issue.

I don't have another display assembly that I can test this with so is there anything I can check for to figure out why there is no backlight?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: In diode mode with red probe on ground and black on Pin 1 of the LCD connector I got 1.20v. Not sure why the number is so high but that is without the charger plugged in and I got that value with and without the LCD plugged in.

threads.message: I need pins 1-10 in diode mode.
